webTitle: Guardian Camera Club: Beancaker's portfolio

fields.standfirst:
A review of Beancaker's portfolio.

'Into The Dark' is a 'film noir' image that starts us thinking about what's going to happen next. The view of 'St Paul's' is rather overshadowed by the heavy post processing and it's questionable as to whether the figures really add to the picture. 'Keep Right' is well composed but the high contrast has lost much of the highlight detail, the blocked out shadows are less important. The multi layered reflections of 'In The Frame' combine to make a street photo, a self portrait, and more. 'One *Explored*' is cinematic for sure, but it still loses too much tonality because of the high contrast. The gritty greys of 'Subway' are excellent, this is the pick of the set. There's some story telling in these photos, they certainly intrigue, but using more subtle processing would be the only advice here
fields.headline: Guardian Camera Club: Beancaker's portfolio
fields.trailText: A review of Beancaker's portfolio

webTitle: Boxer Rebellion in China

fields.standfirst: In 1898, groups of peasants from northern China established a secret society which was named the 'Society of Righteous and Harmonious Fists', known as the 'Boxers' by the Western powers.  They opposed the widespread foreign influence upon China.  By 1900, Christian missionaries were being massacred and on 20 June 1900 the Boxers besieged the foreign quarter in Peking.  Foreign ministers and their families were killed before the siege was finally relieved in August by an international force which had fought its way through northern China
fields.headline: Boxer Rebellion in China
fields.trailText: A photographic highlight from history selected by the picture desk

He joined the Guardian in 2011 from the Daily Telegraph, were he worked for four years as City Diary editor and telecoms and technology correspondent. He was named Student Journalist of the Year at the Guardian Student Media Awards in 2006.
